com.ibm.gaiandb.plugins.wpml

Class PolicyEnabledFilter

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ibm.gaiandb.plugins.wpml.PolicyEnabledFilter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    SQLResultFilter
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    PerfTestingPlugin

    public class PolicyEnabledFilter
extends java.lang.Object
implements SQLResultFilter
    Policy-enabled filter of relational schema elements. Provides an implementation of the filter based on the interface definition made available by GaianDB for plug-in functionality.

    Instantiates a Policy Decision Point (PDP) and a Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) for the policy evaluation and connects to the repository to access the policies that govern the filtering of the data. For now, default file for policies can be found in C:\PFGpolicies.spl. If no such file exists, then the PDP attempts to retrieve policies from a jdbc repository, using connection details found in the wpml.properties file.

    Policy evaluation is performed in 2 steps: first, evaluation of authorization policies is performed, followed by evaluation of the obligation policies.

    Notes/todo list:

    1. Proper logging using the PMLLogger facility (com.ibm.watson.pml.util package)
    2. Update (03/05/2009): the nextQueriedDataSource() method will be deprecated and possibly replaced with verifyDataSources() or something similar. Also, the way the QueryContext is passed to policies for evaluation needs to be changed accordingly
    3. Get configuration for connecting to policy repository a properties file.
    Author:
    pzerfos@us.ibm.com, drvyvyan@uk.ibm.com

      • setLogicalTable

        public boolean setLogicalTable(java.lang.String logicalTableName,
                               java.sql.ResultSetMetaData logicalTableResultSetMetaData)
        Description copied from interface: SQLResultFilter
        Sets the logical table name and its column definitions for the next query to be run. The columns definitions are accessible via a JDBC ResultSetMetaData ojbect. The purpose of this method is to inform the plugin of what logical table is being queried and of its metadata so that it can decide whether to progress with the query (else return false), and make decisions on behaviour in later stages of the query lifecycle...
        Specified by:
        setLogicalTable in interface SQLResultFilter
        Parameters:
        logicalTableName - This can be logical table name or a sub-query expression (if invoked via GaianQuery())

      • nextQueriedDataSource

        public int nextQueriedDataSource(java.lang.String dataSource,
                                 int[] columnMappings)
        Description copied from interface: SQLResultFilter
        Sets the next federated data source of this logical table which is to be queried. If the filter wishes to refuse that this data source be queried (e.g. based on user privileges) it may return 0, in which case it will be skipped. The dataSource argument may idenfity a filename (e.g. './datafile.dat') or an RDBMS table, relative to a database connection URL (e.g. 'jdbc:derby:gaiandb6415;create=true::MYTABLE'). The columnMappings argument describes which logical columns map to which physical ones for this data source, e.g. If columMappings = { 2, 0, 5 }, then it means that the first 3 logical table's columns target columns 3, 1 and 6 in the dataSource which is currently being processed. Notice the column ids are numbered from 0 in the array, but from 1 externally with JDBC. Typically, the purpose of this method is to inform the policy plugin of the column mappings so that it can later make a decision as to how it may want to filter records to be returned...
        Specified by:
        nextQueriedDataSource in interface SQLResultFilter
        Returns:
        the max number of rows that may be returned to this user for this data source, or -1 if unlimited

      • filterRow

        public boolean filterRow(DataValueDescriptor[] row)
        Description copied from interface: SQLResultFilter
        Applies a transformation function to the columns in the row as required by the filter. A row template is passed in as an array of generic SQL columns in Derby DataValueDescriptor column wrappers. The array size and indices match the whole logical table definition, but only the queried columns will be populated. These are given when 'setQueriedColumns' is called. The corresponding physical table's columns can be derived using its columnMappings, which are 0-based, e.g. If columMappings = { 2, 0, 5 }, then it means that the first 3 logical table's columns target columns 3, 1 and 6 in the dataSource which is currently being processed. Notice the column ids are numbered from 0 in the array, but from 1 externally with JDBC. Note that the only way to correlate records being extracted with the data source from which they came would be to have the GaianDB provenance columns available in the set of extracted rows. This implies that the query would itself be including them (using GaianTable options 'with_provenance' or 'explain', or logical table view suffix '_P' or '_X' or '_XF'). The extended interface SQLResultFilterX method filterRowsBatch() addresses this limitation by including a dataSourceID argument.
        Specified by:
        filterRow in interface SQLResultFilter
        Returns:
        false if the row is not to be returned, true if it should be returned (with filters applied on the columns).
